title: Kurius
desc: Joined the youth organization as a mentor for students ranging from highschool to post-secondary to share technology expertise. Currently, I am active on the organization Discord channel to help answer student questions.

title: LIVE Competition
position: Vice President of Engineering, Front-End Developer
desc: Joined the LIVE Competition Executive Team, on the Engineering Team to help improve their competition portal, Blueboard.
I have since been promoted from a front-end developer to the Vice President of Engineering. Currently, I run a team of 5 developers.

As a developer, I was tasked with extending the Blueboard platform for LIVE Competition with intuitive and user-friendly interfaces, the end goal is to ensure that the LIVE team have the resources to continue to make LIVE Competition known as one of Canada’s leading undergraduate business competitions. Meetings are held to capture ideas and implement projects ideas from managers with the help of other developers in the Engineering function.
Weekly sprint meetings are held to update the function on admin and progress details.
Tasks include:

● Collaborate with the Engineering team to design, improve, and maintain the LIVE Competition’s existing Blueboard platform (please see below to learn more), to be used by delegates, partners, judges, and other players
● Helps with the integration of IT Solutions within the LIVE Competition curriculum, and/or for marketing purposes
● Responsible for the development of various other IT initiatives within the LIVE team, to improve overall operational efficiency of the competition
● Finds solutions to, and fixes technological challenges throughout the day of LIVE events (technical support on the day of LIVE events)

title: Women in Computer Science, Statistics, and Mathematics
desc: As a part of the first ever mentorship program with WiCSM, we aim to assist first-year female computer science, mathematics, and statistics students feel a sense of community within the CMS deparment.

Our role is to provide mentor support the students in many different aspects: resume and interview prep, exam prep, study habits, course and program selection, first year advice, campus tours, resources on campus and online.

To do our duties, we stay connected to the mentees through social events and bi-weekly mentor and mentee meetings, scheduled by the mentors. Communication are also held outside of phyiscal meetings, to assist in resolving needs for immediate help

For the new school year, I am now in charge of managing how the mentorship program will run, utilizing my experience as a mentor. I host events for mentors and mentees to meet up, to either have productive discussions on how to succeed or just to hang out with people.

title: Student Ambassador
desc: Starting out as an event staff in first year, I helped set up tear tear down for major events. With a mass volume of people, I guided and clarified inquiries about campus resources, history, university programs, and general university inquires.
After passing a training session to become a tour guide, I guided prospective students and parents through campus in groups of 5 or more people for 45-minute tours.
Tours include knowledge of: campus resources and locations, building locations, campus study spaces, and food options

I was able to enhance my communication skills while talking and touring with strangers and prospective students. It made me proud knowing that giving a tour to prosective students can impact their decision in deciding their post-secondary school. It's also a lot of fun for me to be able to share my own experiences about this campus, and help ensure they'll have a good time as well.

title: Math Kangaroo
desc: I volunteered at an event that was a math contest for students ranging from grade 1 to 12. Before the contest started, I guided participants and parents to respective contest and presentation rooms. During the contest time, I invigilated contest room for grade 5, 7 and 8 students. After the contest was finished, I was a designated marker of contest papers and recorded scores.

title: Math in Motion... Girls in Gear
desc: I volunteered at an event that focuses on empowering grade 9 girls interested in the STEM field. My main role in the morning was administrating the regsitration booth, to give welcome to the students, take their attendance, ensure they filled out the required forms, and hand them each one their goodie bags.
In the afternoon, I was assigned to a group for 4 students to look after during their experiment; by providing materials and timely reminders.
This event was fun to attend; I have never seen so many grade 9 girls being passionate about STEM in one room. They were eager to learn, eager to win, and were a joy to work with.

title: Google's Computer Science Summer Institute
desc: Being one of the 30 students selected to attend this program at Google Cambridge, Boston, MA, I participated at an intensive, three-week coding boot camp focused on gaining skills of programming and web app development. We learned HTML/CSS, Javascript, Python, and Google AppEngine from Google engineers over a two-week period. For the last week, I collaborated with two groupmates to create a final project to demonstrate learnings to peers and Google workers from various parts of the office
(See projects page for more information - Student Connector (Quad-Plus))

title: Leslieville Farmers' Market
desc: Every Sunday, I went to the Farmers' Market to volunteer and assist to run the day smoothly. As an information booth assistant, I administrated the info booth and clarified customer inquires about the market in the 5-hour shift. I also gained access to the cash box and donations in order to ensure protection of market goods as well as to sell the market tote bags.

In connection with the info booth is the children's arts and craft section, which I aided with using caretaking and teaching skills to provide a fun time and ensure their safety at the market while parents shop around the market.
